snippet: In a bereaved Connecticut town, President Obama chided the nation for not having done enough to protect its children from attacks like the one Friday that left 20 elementary school students dead.
abstract: Pres Obama vows to use all the powers of his office to stop massacres like the slaughter at Newtown, Conn, elementary school, hinting at a fresh effort to curb the spread of guns; he delivers assertive speech at a memorial service for the 27 victims, including 20 children, saying that the nation has failed to protect its young, and that is leaders can no longer allow themselves to remain powerless in the face of such carnage.

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER and PETER BAKER
byline.contributor:
Mark Landler reported from Newtown, Conn., and Peter Baker from Washington. Reporting on the Connecticut
shootings was contributed
by Alison Leigh Cowan,
Robert Davey, Joseph Goldstein,
Kia Gregory, Raymond
Hernandez, Thomas
Kaplan, Randy Leonard,
Andy Newman, William K.
Rashbaum, Michael
Schwirtz, Michael D. Shear,
Ravi Somaiya and Vivian
Yee.

lead_paragraph: In a bereaved Connecticut town, President Obama chided the nation for not having done enough to protect its children from attacks like the one Friday that left 20 elementary school students dead.

headline.sub:
‘Newtown, You Are
Not Alone,’ He Tells
Mourners at Vigil
headline.print_headline: Obama Tells Town 'These Tragedies Must End'
